Graphical abstract This review systematically summarizes the recent advances on the synthesis strategies of 2D carbon materials from biomass and biological molecules. Two-dimensional (2D) carbon materials with ultrathin thickness, large lateral size, large surface area, accessible active sites and unique physical–chemical properties have been proven to be attractive electrode materials or catalysts for high-efficient energy storage and conversion materials. However, the conventional synthesis method for 2D carbon materials heavily depends on fossil-based feedstocks and goes through harsh conditions (e.g., chemical vapor deposition), which are unsustainable and costly. Besides, the top-down method needs to use massive strong acids/oxidants, which is environmentally-unfriendly. Therefore, it is necessary to commit to seek green, sustainable and cost-effective approach for the synthesis of 2D carbon materials. As of now, biomass or biological molecules as carbon-rich resources have been viewed as a promising candidate for the 2D carbon material preparation owing to its abundance, renewability, nontoxicity and low-cost. Especially for nucleobases, as an emerging molecule have been shown great advantages for the construction of 2D materials guided by its multiple hydrogen-bonding interaction. Recently, our group have proposed a rather innovative strategy to produce 2D carbon materials by carbonization of nucleobases which has relatively high electrode potentials. These nucleobases can form planar network structure through hydrogen bonding interaction. Such hydrogen-bonding can be stable at relatively high temperature, which confines C–C or C-N polymerization in a 2D plane. As a result, direct carbonization of nucleobases enables the formation of 2D carbon with highly sp2-conjugated and feature of heteroatom doping. This review systematically summarizes the recent development of the strategies to synthesize 2D sustainable carbon materials from biomass and biological molecules. The corresponding electrochemical applications such as lithium ion batteries, supercapacitors and fuel cell are selectively presented. At the end, the summary and future perspectives in this important field are provided to inspire further exploration. Keywords Biomass Nucleobase Two-dimensional carbon Heteroatom-doping Template-free Sustainability 1 Introduction Fossil fuels have contributed to overwhelming majority of the world energy demand due to the rapid industrial development. The increasing consumption of fossil fuels (e.g., coal, oil and natural gas) and accompanied severe environmental issues leading to the urgent development of green, renewable and highly efficient energy storage and conversion technologies [1–3]. Currently, fuel cells, solar cells, water splitting, supercapacitors and lithium-ion batteries etc. represent promising options for clean energy supply [4–6]. However, the performance of the energy storage devices depends primarily on the intrinsic properties of the electrode materials or catalysts such as micro-structure and specific functionality. The sustainability of those materials including simple preparation process, abundant sources, low cost and environmental friendliness needs to be considered prior to industrial-scale application [7–11]. Carbon materials showing great potential among those materials have been exploited, due to their known merits, e.g., excellent electronic conductivity, adjustable microstructure and surface chemistry and good stability, just to name a few their advantages [12–16]. As is well known, the conventional synthesis of carbon materials mainly relies on the direct pyrolysis of organic precursors which mostly derived from fossil fuel sources such as CH4, C2H4, phenol, pitch, and generally under harsh or energy intensive conditions (e.g., chemical vapor deposition). As a result, it is obvious that the conventional synthesis routes of carbon materials are unsustainable and costly [17–20]. Another popular synthetic process to produce functional carbons is top-down path by exfoliation of graphite which involves the use of hazardous reagents. For example, the classical Hummers method to prepare graphene has to use massive strong acid and oxidant, resulting in environmental pollution [21–23]. Therefore, it is meaningful to seek green, sustainable and low-cost method for the synthesis of carbon materials. Biomass or bioprecursor has been regarded as a promising candidate for the preparation of functional carbon materials, since it is abundant, renewable, nontoxic and low-cost [24–29]. Two dimensional (2D) carbons derived from biomass or bioprecursor have attracted tremendous interest, because there are unique advantages of 2D carbon materials for energy related applications, such as large surface area (theoretically up to 2630 m2/g), capacity of providing a 2D area carrying abundant active sites for redox reactions, and easy accessible inner-outer interfaces of the 2D architecture [30–35]. Due to relatively high HOMO energy level, carbonization or polymerization of biomass which contains abundant oxygen groups often results in the formation of ill-defined carbon in terms of their connection motifs, local hybridization, and aromatic structures. To obtain highly sp2-conjugated, long-range ordered and porous carbons, the carbonization of biomass frequently takes place in a confined template or requires the assistance of metal catalysts [36]. By contrast, carbon with ordered structure and specific properties can be constructed by self-assembly of nucleobases that has lower HOMO energy level as building units via H-bonding and π-π staking interaction [37]. This kind of carbon has been called “noble” carbon and display strong oxidation resistance, which is beneficial for catalysis application. Although some relevant reviews on the topic of chemical approach for carbon materials synthesis have been reported [25,28,34,35]. There is still no systematic focus on the synthesis of 2D sustainable carbon materials derived from biomass or bioprecursor so far. In this review, we summarize the recent development of the synthetic strategies for 2D carbons derived from biomass or bioprecursor, as well as their important applications in energy related systems (Table 1 and Scheme 1 ). 2 Hard template method Hard template method is one of the most common methods to the fabrication of well-defined carbon materials. Typically, the method includes the following steps: preparing the template, mixing the carbon precursor with the template, pyrolyzing the composite, and finally removing the template. The nanostructures of the resultant 2D products are thus influenced by the original template structure, molecular recognition between the template and carbon precursor, and even the post-treatment. Despite of these tedious processes and some safety problems, it is the most promising method to accurately regulate the porous structure, thickness, and uniformity of carbon nanosheets. One of the limitations of the method is that, the residuals of template often remain within the products, leading to loss or reduction of catalytic performance of 2D carbons. In this section, several representative examples are introduced for this method. 2.1 Common 2D templates The common 2D materials (such as 2D metallic oxide or metal hydroxide, layered silicate or montmorillnite, boric acid, MgAl-layered double oxides (LDO) nanosheets, 2D transition-metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), etc.) with unique properties have widely been used as hard templates for fabricating 2D carbon-based materials [38–40]. For instance, montmorillonite with the unique intercalation and ion exchange properties could be easily inserted by various carbonaceous precursors [41,42]. Bakandritsos et al. described a typical route to produce graphene-like materials by intercalating sugar into smectite clays, followed by thermal treatment above 600 °C and hydrofluoric acid demineralization [43]. Tang et al. fabricated a N-doped defective graphene-like materials through selecting gelatinized sticky rice as a carbon precursor, melamine as a nitrogen source and Mg(OH)2 as the template, followed by carbonization and purification (Fig. 1 ). The resultant sample exhibited excellent ORR and OER performance with an overpotential gap of 0.90 V in 0.1 M KOH solution, simultaneously revealing the critical role of edge and topological defects in oxygen electrocatalysis for metal-free nanocarbon materials (Fig. 1) [44]. Ling et al. reported B/N co-doped carbon nanosheets via assembling the gelatin as the carbon and nitrogen source in long-range order on 2D hard template of boric oxide (derived from boric acid) which also served as the boron source. During the evaporative crystallization process for boric acid aqueous solution containing gelatin, the gelatin molecule was assembled into the planes of boric acid crystals, preventing their layer-by-layer growth and restacking. After annealing at 900 °C, the gelatin layer was converted to carbon nanosheets, while boric acid was decomposed to boron oxide, which could be removed by refluxing in boiling water. The product with a specific surface area of 416 m2/g and thickness of 5–8 nm showed capacitances of 210 F/g at 1 A/g in 1 M H2SO4 electrolyte as well as 223 F/g at 0.1 A/g in 6 M KOH electrolyte (Fig. 2 ) [45]. 2.2 Molten salt method Recently, Antonietti’s group [46–49] proposed a molten salt route to synthesize porous carbon nanosheets. In a typical process, glucose was mixed with a deep eutectic mixture (e.g., LiCl/KCl, 45/55 in mass ratio, the melting point of 353 °C) with or without containing the activating oxysalt (e.g., KNO3, K2SO4, KClO3) in certain ratio using a ball-milling method. The homogeneous mixture was then transferred to the oven, heated to the reaction temperature (>500 °C) with a 5 K/min heating rate and held for 5 h in N2 atmosphere. After cooling down to room temperature and grinding, the product was thoroughly washed by water and collected. For example, with heating the glucose and LiCl/KCl mixture at different weight ratios (1:10 or 1:100), solvent effects on the as-formed carbon structures were observed [48]. The sample prepared at a weight ratio of 1:10 and pyrolysis temperature at 800 °C showed mixed morphologies of thick layered structures and irregular shaped carbon particles. However, with decreasing the glucose concentration, the fraction of sheet-like carbon in the final product increased remarkably. When the glucose/salt ratio was 1:100, the product was dominated by the sheet-like structures (Fig. 3 ). It suggested that a solution growth mechanism was involved for the formation of carbon products. The low concentrations of precursor enable the carbonaceous intermediates being dissolved by the molten salt and converted completely to graphene layers. In other words, the nanosheet morphology is formed only when the carbon-containing intermediates are dissolved in liquefied molten salts medium and growing into graphene. These optimal nanosheets had turbostratic structures, the thickness ranging from 0.7 to 7 nm, with a specific surface area of 595 m2/g and strong hydrophobicity [48]. When adding dissolved oxysalts into the system, the situation would become different [46,47]. As glucose: oxysalt: LiCl/KCl was fixed at the weight ratio of 1:1:10, according to the oxysalt type, the products showed different morphologies, for instance, irregularly interconnected carbon particles and graphene-like carbon nanosheets (Fig. 3). It was found that carbonate, nitrate, sulfate and chlorate, were efficient in not only creating pores but also facilitating the 2D growth of carbonaceous intermediates. Taking the best system using KClO3 as an oxysalt for further investigation, the synthesis temperature was proposed to have no evident influence on the microstructure of the product. Meanwhile, more layer structure seemed to be formed at higher KClO3/glucose (K/G) ratio (e.g., K/G = 1). However, when K/G ratio was up to 2, it was accompanied by a greatly reduced yield and loss of porous texture, suggesting the effect of oxysalt concentration was complicated. The optimized nanosheets obtained at K/G = 1 possessed the thickness of ca. 10 nm, specific surface area of 1252 m2/g and S-dopant. It was evident that the molten salt process not only generated porosity but also allowed controllably fabricating of 2D carbon sheets. The generation of porosity was similar to the chemical activation process, where part of the as-formed carbon intermediate was oxidized by the added oxysalt. As for the 2D growth mechanisms, the authors speculated that sp 2 C–C bonding energetically favored 2D assembly of carbonaceous intermediates mediated by ionic environment. The growth of 2D carbon sheet then started by organizing these primitive structures to large micrometer-scale sheets. The detailed mechanisms still needed to be further investigated [47]. 2.3 NH4Cl foaming method Wang et al. synthesized a kind of 3D strutted graphene (SG) by controllable pyrolysis of glucose and NH4Cl mixture, which is called “sugar blowing” approach and it is quite similar to the traditional polymer foaming process (Fig. 4 ). During this process, the molten syrup was gradually polymerized, wherein the released gases from NH4Cl blew sugar-derived polymers into numerous large bubbles. The gas release, blowing and surface-tension-induced drainage were gradually thinning the bubble walls, which were subsequently carbonized into ultrathin graphitic membranes at the high temperature. The structural regulation of SG was achieved by modulating heating rates. The heating rate works via the matching relation between the polymer curing and gas release owing to kinetics factors, involving the decomposition of NH4Cl, gas diffusion, nucleation and growth of bubbles. The produced SG could possess few-layered thickness of ca. 20 nm, large specific surface area of ca. 1000 m2/g, and high yield up to 16 ± 5 wt% in the pyrolysis condition of 1350 °C for 3 h at a heating rate of 4 °C/min, exhibiting to be high-power high-energy electrochemical capacitors [50]. Similarly, Jiang et al. reported a spontaneous gas-foaming method to fabricate N-doped carbon nanosheets via simply pyrolyzing the mixture of citric acid and NH4Cl. Here, NH4Cl not only acted as a nitrogen source, but also served as a foaming agent to form the 3D cross-linked porous network structure, because it could be decomposed into the gases of NH3 and HCl in the carbonization process. For comparison, without using NH4Cl, only large carbon blocks can be obtained even carbonizing at 1000 °C, demonstrating the function of NH4Cl to form sheet structure. Moreover, it was found that both the carbonization temperature and the mass ratio of precursors were crucial for regulating the morphology and structure of resultant carbon nanosheets. Under the optimized pyrolytic condition with temperature at 1000 °C and precursor mass ratio of 1:1, the as-synthesized sample possessed the ultrathin sheet-like structure, high specific surface area of 1793 m2/g and enriched defect sites, showing excellent activities and stability for ORR, OER and HER. By density functional theory (DFT) computations, they suggested that the intrinsic active sites were the carbon atoms adjacent to the graphitic-N configuration and located at the armchair edge [51]. 3 Soft template method Self-assembly of amphiphilic molecules can form lamellar structures under appropriate conditions [52–56]. For example, the hydrophobic alkyl chains construct a planar bilayer sandwiched by two hydrophilic layers in aqueous solution, which is an ideal soft template to prepare sheet-like materials. Besides, carbon precursors can also be adsorbed on the surface of soft templates through hydrogen bonding or electrostatic interaction, which afford more possibilities to control structures of the products via varying the nature of amphiphile, solvent, temperature, pH, additives, and so on. Our group synthesized a new kind of graphene-like carbons derived from biomass via a hydrothermal process with the assistance of a soft-template (Fig. 5 ). Sodium oleate (SO) and P123 (EO20-PO70-EO20) were chosen as the double surfactants to form mixed micelles in aqueous solution owing to their hydrophobic nature and strong interaction. Diverse carbohydrates (i.e. glucose, fructose and cellulose) served as carbon precursors and biomolecule guanine as a powerful nitrogen source. During the hydrothermal process, glucose first dehydrated to 5-hydroxymethyl furfural, then reacted with guanine via the Schiff base reaction between the carbonyl groups in 5-hydroxymethyl furfural and the amino appended to guanine. At the same time, the condensation and assembly took place around micelle droplets by the weak interaction. Through above reactions, a unique composite has been formed. After pyrolysis, the inner soft-templates were gradually decomposed and removed, while the outermost thin layer of hydrothermal-based products were further graphitized and shrunk to form curly carbon nanosheets. The 2D product with a high specific surface area up to 974 m2/g and in-situ nitrogen-doped content of 2.39 at% exhibited high performance toward both ORR and HER. The half-wave potential could be up to 0.87 V (vs. RHE) and a large diffusion-limited current density of 5.9 mA/cm2 for ORR was achieved, which outperformed most other equivalent benchmarks and Pt-based catalysts [57]. In brief, this method is a relatively eco-friendly proposal to construct the lamellae, and removal of the template could be accomplished through nontoxic or noncorrosive processes. It generally presents more flexible and possible in morphological control than the hard template method. Nevertheless, the stability of soft templates is inferior to hard templates, which should be further improved. Additionally, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4), which is a kind of layered conjugated organic semiconductor composed of sp 2 hybridized C and N atoms [58], has also widely been used as a nitrogen source, 2D template and porogen to fabricate N-doped carbon nanosheets. Originally, Li et al. [59] adopted the two-step pyrolysis of a mixture of dicyandiamide (DCDA) and glucose to get the final products. During this process, the glucose-derived aromatic carbon intermediates wrapped on the as-formed g-C3N4 surface possibly by their donor–acceptor interactions or confined the condensation in the interlayer gaps of g-C3N4 at ca. 600 °C. Because the g-C3N4 template tended to complete decomposition above 700 °C, the final graphene-like structure was liberated at a higher temperature (Fig. 6 ). It was worth noting that the layered thickness and specific surface area were strongly dependent on the DCDA/glucose mass ratio (M d/g). The minimum M d/g value for forming flakes was ca. 10. When the value was 5, only bulky carbon was observed. As M d/g was altered from 40 to 10, the specific surface area of the products synthesized at 800 °C decreased from 975 to 331 m2/g. The sample obtained at the M d/g value of 40 and 1000 °C possessed a nitrogen content of 4.3 at%, density of 0.0077 g/cm3, bulk conductivity of 785 S/m and high specific surface area of 820 m2/g, yet a wide-range thickness likely resulted from the incomplete mixing of precursors. Yu et al. firstly prepared g-C3N4 nanosheets by the thermal decomposition-polymerization of urea. Then, glucose-based carbonized intermediates were loaded onto both sides of g-C3N4 surface via a hydrothermal process to form the g-C3N4@glucose hybrid. After pyrolysis at 900 °C, the hybrid was converted into N-doped carbon nanosheets (Fig. 7 ). It was found that the properties of products, such as the thickness, porosity and N content could be adjusted by the hydrothermal temperature (HT). With increasing the HT, thicker glucose carbonized products coated on g-C3N4, thicker carbon sheets with lower specific surface area and N content was generated. The optimized sample with a specific surface area of 1077 m2/g and N content up to 11.6 at% showed a comparable ORR activity to Pt/C catalyst in alkaline medium [60]. Apart from glucose as the precursor, citric acid, poly(ionic liquid) and even bacterial cellulose were used as carbon sources to synthesize 2D based carbon materials [61–63]. Ye et al. reported a “vein-leaf” type 3D complex with nitrogen-doped graphene as the leaf and carbon nanofibers as the skeleton via simple pyrolysis of a mixture of bacterial cellulose (BC) and urea at 900 °C. During the process, the carbonaceous intermediates generated from the BC carbonization diffused into the interlayer of g-C3N4 and then were thermally condensed into carbon nanosheets. The resultant hybrid with a specific surface area of 206 m2/g and N content of 9.82 at% delivered high ORR performance owing to the robust interconnected 3D network conductive to both mass diffusion and electron transfer in electrochemical reactions [63]. 4 KOH based method It is common to achieve graphene-like morphology through KOH activated method. The KOH activation is a widely known method to create the pore network in carbons, yet the activation mechanism has not reached a consensus because of a large number of variables generating during activation process. In a general view, the following activation mechanism contains three steps is widely accepted: (1) the chemical activation, i.e. etching of the carbon framework by various redox reactions between potassium compounds (K2O, K2CO3) and carbon, is mainly responsible for introducing the pore network; (2) the formation of H2O and CO2 likely contributes to the further development of porosity by the gasification of carbon, i.e. the physical activation; (3) the as-formed metallic K (above 700 °C) can be intercalated into the carbon lattices, resulting in the expansion of the lattices. After removing of the intercalated metallic K, the expanded carbon lattices cannot back to their initial state and thus possibly form the carbon sheets (Fig. 8 ). However, the real activation processes and mechanisms are variable depending on the activation parameters (e.g., ratio of KOH, activation temperature, etc.) and the reactivity of different carbon sources (e.g., coals, pitches, biomass, synthetic organic polymers and diverse structured carbons) [64,65]. For the above reasons, not all products activated by KOH present flake morphologies. The natural biomass-based carbon sources with multilayered structure tend to generate the graphene-like structures when combined with KOH activation. For instance, Zhang et al. reported a kind of S/N co-doped graphene-like nanobubble and nanosheet hybrids synthesized by using keratin as the precursor, KOH as the activating agent, and further graphitization and ammonia treatments at 1000 °C. In detail, the precursor was first precarbonized at 300 °C for 0.5 h. Then the precarbonized product was mixed with KOH at a weight ratio of 1:2, and further activated at 600 °C for 2 h. After acid-leaching to remove potassium-containing compounds, it was finally subjected to graphitization and ammonia treatment at 1000 °C. The graphene-like product shown high specific surface area of 1799 m2/g, N content of 1.5 at% and S content of 0.1 at% displayed high activity as well as stability in both alkaline and acidic media for ORR. It is worth mentioning that although the lamellar structure existing in the main cysteine skeletal components of keratin, the direct carbonized product (without using KOH) only showed a typical bulk carbon structure with ultra low porosity. Thus it demonstrated that the KOH activation played important roles in both developing the porosity and in the formation of graphene-like structure [66]. As another example, Li et al. reported using willow catkin with a hollow and multi-layered fiber structure as the precursor combined with KOH activation to prepare S/N co-doped porous carbon nanosheets. Especially, without presence of KOH, the final pyrolysis sample shown tubular and thin-walled structure inherited from the initial willow catkin fiber. With the increase of KOH ratio, the product gradually turned into 3D interconnected carbon nanosheets (Fig. 9 ). Due to lacking adequate KOH activation, only part of the product was peeled off into carbon nanosheets. As a result, the optimal N/S co-doped sample exhibited a high specific capacitance of 298 F/g at 0.5 A/g, excellent rate performance and good cycling stability in supercapacitor application [67]. Hemp and wheat straw had the multilevel layered structure composed of cellulose, hemicellulose and lignin, wherein the cellulose layer was surrounded by hemicellulose layer and lignin layer [68,69]. Wang et al. reported using hemp bast fiber as the precursor combined with hydrothermal and activation processes to achieve graphene-like carbon nanosheets (Fig. 10 ). Under the hydrothermal condition at 180 °C, most of S3 layer (mainly composed of hemicellulose)) and part of S1 layer (mainly composed of lignin) were converted into soluble organic compounds, while S2 layer (mainly composed of cellulose) was partially carbonized. Hence the hemicellulose and lignin layers were removed, while the cellulose layer was loosened. In the subsequent activation process, the metallic K penetrated into the loose layers, resulting in full separation of layers into sheets. The thickness of carbon nanosheets decreased when increasing the activation temperature, which was 50–100 nm at 700 °C, 40–70 nm at 750 °C, and 10–30 nm at 800 °C. The resultant porous carbon nanosheets possessed high specific surface area of 1500–2300 m2/g and exhibited good electrical conductivity (211–226 S/m) and high supercapacitor performance [68]. Water hyacinth possesses thin cell walls and large intercellular spaces, which is beneficial to preparing large porous sheet-like carbon materials. Wu et al. used water hyacinth as the precursor via the acid treatment, carbonization and alkali activation to fabricate large porous carbon sheets. The final carbon sheets with a large specific surface of 1308 m2/g delivered a high specific capacitance of 273F/g at a current density of 1 A/g, good capacity retention and superior cyclic stability in 6 M KOH [70]. Hao et al. tried to exfoliate the multilayered structure of ginkgo leaves via hydrothermal treatment and KOH activation (Fig. 11 ). It was observed that the KOH content significantly influenced the morphology of the final products. Lacking adequate KOH activation led to incomplete exfoliation, and only few nanosheets peeled off from the matrix, which confirmed the intercalation and exfoliation abilities of K compounds [71]. Liu et al. proposed a synthetic method for biomass-derived porous carbon nanosheets with the assistance of KOH by using fish scale as the precursor. As one kind of biomass waste, fish scales are abundant in collagen and can be applied to extract gelatin in alkali or acid solution. They extracted gelatin from fish scales in KOH solution at 80 °C at the first step. The mixture was then lyophilized, wherein gelatin coated on KOH templates due to the film-forming property of gelatin. Finally, it was subjected to activation and pyrolysis at high temperature. The resultant porous carbon nanosheets with specific surface area of 962 m2/g and 5.05 at% of N content showed the high gravimetric and volumetric capacitance performance for supercapacitors [72]. Besides KOH, other K-containing compounds such as KCl and KHCO3 can also intercalate mental K into the carbon layers while creating pores, thus separating the sheets smoothly and even resulting in thinner carbon nanosheets. Wang et al. prepared a nanoporous and graphene-like carbon material derived from a natural silk with the KCl activation. Bombyx mori silk was chosen as precursor, which possessed an oriented β-sheet crystal structure and a lamellar-like layer among all of the cocoons. The carbonized fibers from original silk fiber without KCl presented the smooth surface. However, after using KCl, the architecture of the obtained fiber consisted of graphene-like nanosheets due to the K intercalation effect, and showing better ORR performance [73]. Mondal et al. reported KHCO3 activation method to prepare N-doped porous carbon nanosheets by choosing eucalyptus leaves as the precursor. The products with specific surface area of 2133 m2/g were composed of interconnected nanosheets with slightly thick and small-sized morphology, showing the high performance in supercapacitor and lithium ion battery applications [74]. 5 Template-free method Template-free method is a direct strategy to prepare 2D carbon materials without the assistance of any structure-guiding agent or metal-based growth catalyst (such as Fe/Ni/Co/Cr) in the synthetic process. The precursors can spontaneously form 2D carbon frameworks after some pre-treatment and subsequent direct pyrolysis. It is quite different from the hard template or soft template methods which with relatively complicated protocols. Meanwhile, it is also eco-friendly without using toxic reagents. However, this template-free method is somewhat not efficient in precisely regulating the morphology and porosity of products. In this part, several typical kinds of template-free strategies for 2D carbon synthesis are shown and discussed. Abundant natural biomass resources generally show various structures such as multilevel macroscopic or microscopic layered structure, and thus are encouraged to prepare diverse carbon-based nanosheets. However, the flake structures cannot be retained perfectly after the direct carbonization, instead, they tend to transform into the bulk products instead of the initial layered structures. Therefore, some auxiliary strategies are considered to be used in combination. Freeze-drying technique might be a good choice to remain their initial microstructure. For example, a kind of sheet-like porous carbon was synthesized by Li et al. using eggplant as the precursor combined with freeze drying technique (Fig. 12 ). Eggplant is chosen as the carbon precursor due to its inherent sheet-like structure on microscale. The freeze-drying treatment was pre-conducted aiming to maintain the original flake structure. After one-step carbonization, a high specific surface area of 950 m2/g, N-doping and the sheet thickness in the range of 100–200 nm were achieved. It can be used as a promising electrode material for high rate supercapacitors due to the short ion diffusion paths [75]. Ling et al. fabricated a sheet-shaped carbon cryogel via selecting chitosan as the carbon and nitrogen source, combined with freeze-drying process. Direct carbonization of pristine chitosan achieved irregularly shaped and dense carbon particles. However, the sheet-like shape could be obtained after carbonization of pre-freeze-drying sample, showing the thickness ranges from 5 to 8 μm (Fig. 13 ). The resultant sheet-shaped carbon material with the specific surface area up to 1025 m2/g and high nitrogen content of 5.98 wt% showed evident enhancement for supercapacitor and lithium ion storage performance compared with those of direct-carbonized carbon particles [76]. By contrast, there are some biomass with obvious sheet structure macroscopically, which are supposed to get flaky morphology after direct carbonization, such as diverse leaves. However, it was proved that the products included not only carbon nanosheets, but also other bulk or granular carbons. Thus the quality of products was not good, and it needed centrifugation or other post-treatment to isolate nanosheets from the mixture. For instance, Shams et al. reported a direct method to prepare few layer graphene from camphor leaves via one-step pyrolysis. However, the direct carbonized products contained not only ultrathin sheets, but also other components, such as bulky particles derived from the leaf vein (Fig. 14 ). To obtain targeted graphene, follow up process was needed. The pyrolytic carbon compounds were mixed with D-Tyrosine and trichloromethane, and sonicated for 15 min to separate each component. High speed centrifugation (5000 rpm, 5 min) was then applied to precipitating carbon particles and suspended targeted graphene in the supernatant. The π–π interactions between graphene and D-Tyrosine could stabilize the supernatant solution. Since D-Tyrosine was soluble in strong acids or bases, it could be removed from the suspension by washing with a strong acid or base. The obtained graphene with a thickness of ca. 7 layers, a specific surface area of about 296 m2/g, and a yield of 0.8%. Therefore, because of these complicated preparation processes and low yield, it is not proposed to be a facile and scalable strategy to produce graphene [77]. After simplifying the procedures, Pan et al. synthesized a kind of N-doped porous carbon nanosheets by directly carbonization of ginkgo leaves, combined with the ammonia post-treatment to introduce N and generate nanopores. However, the product consisted of sheets and bulky carbon, and the laminar component was relatively limited. Thus it is also not a good choice to produce carbon nanosheets [78]. Similarly, Liu et al. used perilla frutescens leaves as the precursor to synthesize N/O-doped porous carbon nanosheets by the direct pyrolysis. The optimal sample (at 700 °C) presented O and N contents respectively of 18.76 at% and 1.70 at%, together with a moderate specific surface area of 655 m2/g, showing a high gravimetric capacitance (270 F/g at 0.5 A/g) for supercapacitors. However, it was still composed of nanosheets, nanorods as well as nanoparticles, corresponding to the products carbonized from different components of leaves (Fig. 15 ) [79]. There are also some controversial examples. Liao et al. selected nori–marine algae, which had a special thin-film structure and was rich in N, P and other elements (even trace of iron), as the precursor and melamine as the promoter to prepare graphene-like carbon materials. Treatment processes of the product involved hydrothermal carbonization and subsequent pyrolysis. The final product with N content of 2.63 at% and specific surface area of 538 m2/g exhibited excellent ORR performance. The authors suggested that adding melamine was able to enhance the catalyst’s N content, and this sheet-like structure was attributable to the original thin-film morphology of nori. However, the morphology of the contrasted sample without adding melamine as the promoter was not clearly provided. Melamine is a well-known precursor to synthesize g-C3N4, which can serve as a kind of 2D sacrificial templates. Thus this strategy needs to be further considered whether it is a real template-free method [80,81]. Additionally, Hao et al. synthesized chitosan-based carbon sheets through freeze–drying and KOH activation. The thickness of main sheets observed from SEM images was ranging from 1 μm to 3 μm corresponding to the different temperatures from 700 °C to 900 °C. However, they found ultrathin thickness was 13 nm for 800 °C and 1.5 nm for 900 °C from AFM data, which were likely corresponding to some small fragments exfoliated by the KOH activation. The resultant sample with high specific surface area of ca. 2000 cm3/g and N-self-doped property showed a specific capacitance of about 197 F/g at a current density of 0.2 A/g and good cyclability [82]. Similarly, Zhu et al. used chitosan to synthesize N-doped porous carbon nanobelt with the assistance of ZnCl2 and CoCl2 salts. It was found that the added metal salts as effective activation–graphitization agents play a key role on determining the final microstructure and graphitization degree, which was demonstrated by the fact that the pure N-doped carbons (without usage of ZnCl2 and CoCl2 salts) delivered a low graphitization degree and irregular morphology [83]. Therefore, it can be seen that chitosan is not a direct 2D carbonaceous precursor, which must be combined with other strategies such as lyophilization, KOH activation or metal-based growth catalyst. 6 Nucleobases derived 2D carbons Carbohydates, such as glucose, have relatively low electrode potential. By hydrothermal carbonization or direct annealing, they will produce water and carbon. When water (+1.23 V) is eliminated [36], the residual material moves upward in internal energy, leading to the formation of reductive carbon with ill-defined structure and less-developed porosity. This is consistent with the fact that such carbon is an effective carbothermal reductant able to reduce iron salts to iron or iron carbide [84]. If we select another precursor, such as nucleobases, which have high electrode potential, the carbonized path would go in a different direction. After elimination of water, CO2, CO, NH3, or N2 under elevated temperature, which have low electrode potential than the nucleobases, the residuals move downward in the internal energy. Therefore, the electrode potential of this kind of carbon is confined by the initial molecule, as shown in Fig. 16 . Such noble carbon usually contains high-level heteroatom-dopants and high oxidation resistant ability, and consists of highly sp 2-conjugated, long-range ordered and porous carbon. This idea could provide a completely new avenue to construct 2D carbon materials by carbonization of selected precursors. In view of above, our group proposed a rather innovative strategy to produce 2D carbon materials, wherein biomolecule guanine was chosen as the specific precursor [37]. Guanine can serve as both a hydrogen bond donor and a hydrogen bond acceptor. Generally, four guanine bases form a G-quartet connected by eight Hoogsteen hydrogen bonds. Then several G-quartet unit cells expand to a larger planar network structure through additional hydrogen bonds. The planar networks are usually stacked together by weak π-π interactions (Fig. 17 ) [85–87]. The crystalline structure of guanine makes it very promising to be a precursor for the preparation of two-dimensional materials. On the other hand, guanine is a kind of biomass extract. In recent years, with the increasing development of biological extraction technologies, the sources of guanine have become more extensive. Therefore, Guanine as precursor has a sustainable competitive advantage. In addition, considering its definite molecular structure, it is more reliable to investigate the carbonization mechanism and reproducibly optimize the catalytic performance of products. Therefore, it is preferable to select guanine as a precursor for 2D nanocarbons. Typically, direct pyrolysis of guanine at above 800 °C in N2 atmosphere unprecedentedly formed few-layer carbon with in situ high N doping level (Fig. 18 ). Moreover, by pre-ionizing guanine which is containing an amino in the molecular structure with the acids (e.g., H2SO4, H3PO4, H3BO3), a group of multiple heteroatom (N/O/S/P/B) doped 2D carbons with adjustable porous structures could also be readily achieved [37]. It is worth noting that the synthetic process was quite simple and efficient, without any pre-treatments (such as freeze drying to keep the morphology), the assistance of K containing compound activation and the final removal of 2D template. The products exhibited the intriguing properties, e.g., uniform morphology, large lateral size, ultrathin thickness (ca. 1 nm), high-level heteroatom dopants, large specific surface area (ca. 500 m2/g) and hierarchically porous structure (particularly the significant mesoporosity). Owing to these merits, it representatively delivered the superior ORR performance with a half-wave potential of 0.84 V vs. RHE and diffusion-limited current density of 5.40 mA/cm2, outperforming most of graphene-based catalysts and even the Pt/C catalyst. Besides, the high yields (ca.10 wt% even at 1000 °C), low cost, facile and controllable process made it meet the requirement of large-scale preparation. Interestingly, due to the existence of multiple supramolecular interactions, such as H-bonding, π-π, dipole–dipole, carbonization of other nucleobases would spontaneously lead to the formation of 2D heteroatom-doping carbon materials. Moreover, this method also shows excellent flexibility. When combined with the SiO2 nanoparticles, a 3D graphene-based framework was built up (Fig. 19 ), which inherited the unique 2D structure from guanine-derived carbons and significantly differed from common silica template-based products [88]. In addition, we also found that it can successfully construct a 3D graphene-based carbon material by applying a CO2 activation method [89]. It has shown that with the extension of CO2 treatment time, the two-dimensional carbon substrates are etched thinner and more curved, thus overlapping to form a unique three-dimensional architecture. It is a relatively simple and low-cost strategy, illustrating the flexibility of guanine-derived two-dimensional carbon materials. The optimized 3D materials exhibit excellent ORR performance, not only due to the presence of abundant active sites, but also the unique advantages of a three-dimensional structure constituted by the interconnection of ultrathin and curly carbon nanosheets. Engineering of the microstructure and intrinsic active sites of nanocarbon-based catalysts is extremely crucial for diverse sustainable energy-conversion systems. Inspired by this, we have explored a facile but efficient strategy to prepare a new kind of pyridinic-N dominated porous carbon nanosheets with the edge-enriched defective nature through using guanine as C/N precursor and tactfully combination with in-situ ZnCl2 activation (Fig. 20 ) [90]. Besides the creation of numerous pores and holes by ZnCl2 constantly corroding the carbon matrix and evaporation of metallic Zn, at the same time a large number of edges and defects were also induced, which was highly beneficial to achieving N-doping at edges or defect sites and thus generating pyridinic-N which belongs to a edge N dopant. Systematic study reveals that both ZnCl2 ratio and annealing temperatures can play the critical role of effectively regulating the microstructure and intrinsic active sites. Consequently, the most optimized catalyst of G1000-ZC-2.0 delivers the highly impressive catalytic performances toward ORR in pH-universal condition, reflecting on possessing 30 mV more positive E 1/2 (0.885 V) than Pt/C (0.855 V) catalyst in 0.1 M KOH, and having very close activities to Pt/C in 0.1 M PBS and 0.1 M HClO4 solution. This outstanding ORR performance can attribute to the special synergistic effect of unique graphene-like architecture, well-developed porosity, the coexistence of high-level active pyridinic-N species and abundant intrinsic edge/defect sites. It is highly expected to pave the way for performance-oriented design principle and engineering construction of an outstanding ORR catalyst in the most challenging pH-universal condition. Based on this method, a novel kind CNT-graphene 3D hybrid was fabricated by effectively integrating of CNTs with heteroatom-doped graphene derived from guanine precursor (Fig. 21 ). It was believed that the graphene provided a 2D field carrying abundant active sites for redox reactions, while CNTs served as a bridge to efficiently deliver electrons. Such synergistic 3D architecture accompanied with a developed porous structure which was beneficial to mass transfer, exhibiting high activities toward ORR/OER/HER as well as high performance in Zn-air batteries [91]. In view of the unique morphology and structural advantages of these guanine-derived carbon materials (such as ultrathin two-dimensional properties and uniform heteroatom-doping characteristics), it is also an ideal choice for new metal carriers that can support various metals for more reactions. For example, we synthesized a kind of novel N-doped carbon nanosheets supporting highly dispersed single iron atoms by one-step pyrolyzing the mixture of guanine and ferric nitrate (Fig. 22 ) [92]. High angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) image clearly disclosed that the iron was uniformly dispersed and isolated as single atoms on the surface of 2D carbons. Resulting from the formation of abundant Fe-N x active sites, the as-prepared Fe-N x -C catalyst exhibited an excellent ORR performance with a half-wave potential up to 0.85 V. Additionally, a new kind of N/S co-doped carbon nanosheets supporting well-dispersed rhodium nanoparticles was successfully prepared via a simple impregnation method (Fig. 23 ) [93]. The results of X-ray photoelectron spectra indicated that the introduction of sulfur in graphene-like nanosheets enhanced the interaction between carbon supports and Rh nanoparticles, which promoted the electrons to deviate from Rh and transfer into the interface of Rh and carbon, resulting in a novel interface catalyst. Benefiting from the presence of an electron-rich interface, this as-synthesized Rh-based interface catalyst displayed superior HER activities in the wide pH range even in actual seawater (pH = 8.32), very close to the commercial 20 wt% Pt/C catalyst when the Rh loading was only 0.5 wt%. This work might provide a new route to design very promising electrocatalysts for seawater splitting. Moreover, Pd nanoparticles (~2.1 nm) supported on guanine-derived graphene-like carbons have been studied as highly active and stable catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of quinolines [94]. The XPS results indicated that the intensity ratio of Pd0/Pd2+ increased in N/S co-doped graphene-like carbons, suggesting a significant correlation between support property and Pd electronic structure. Finally, N/O/S-codoped Pd@GS1000 showed substantially enhanced activity for quinoline hydrogenation reactions with > 99% conversion and > 99% selectivity to 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline in mild catalytic condition, which was superior to Pd@G1000 (without sulfur doping) and Pd/OCNT (the reference catalyst). Further investigation indicated that sulfur codoped carbon nanosheets strongly interacted with metal, thus metallic Pd was regarded as an active center for hydrogenation reactions. This work provided a potential for the development of supported catalysts based on ultrathin carbon nanosheets in fine chemical production. 7 Summary and outlook In summary, we have reviewed the recent developments of novel synthetic strategies for 2D carbon materials from renewable bio-resources by highlighting some typical examples, coupled with their applications in various electrochemical processes such as supercapacitors, lithium batteries and ORR electrocatalysis. The advantages and its limitations of each method are summarized as follows: (1) The advantages of hard-template method: For common 2D templates (e.g., 2D metal hydroxide, layered montmorillnite, MgAl-layered double oxides (LDO), 2D transition-metal dichalcogenides (TMDs)), the deformation of hard templates can be negligible in the synthesis process and the structure of resultant materials enables faithful replication from the templates, resulting in the successful preparation of 2D materials with tunable structure and morphology. For the molten-salt strategy, the specific surface area of product is adjustable in a wide range of ca. 200 m2/g–4000 m2/g, meanwhile the thickness can also range from micrometer to nanometer by fine regulation. For the NH4Cl foaming method, it requires no extra removal of template due to the complete decomposition of NH4Cl at high temperature, meanwhile achieving in situ nitrogen-doping property. However, there still exist some limitations or drawbacks for the hard-template method. Generally, the uniformity of the product is highly related to the mixed situation of carbon source and 2D template. Besides, the adequate amount of template must be guaranteed, otherwise the quality of 2D product is unsatisfactory (such as the low ratio of sheets and thick morphology), which somewhat results in relatively low yields and inefficiency. Moreover, the common 2D template routes are tedious, and the removal of templates with toxic agents (such as HF or NaOH) may bring severe problems in safety and environment. For the molten-salt route, it is still hard to fully disclose the detailed mechanisms. For the NH4Cl foaming method, the synthetic process is producing tremendous hazardous gases (NH3 and HCl), easily spouting out of the sealed tube furnace and leading to an inefficient preparation. (2) The soft-template method generally presents more flexibility and possibility in morphological control than the hard template method. Meanwhile, the removal of template is via the nontoxic or noncorrosive process and relatively eco-friendly. Nevertheless, the stability of soft templates is lower than hard templates, which should be further improved. For the g-C3N4 template, it doesn't require the extra removal of template due to the complete decomposition of g-C3N4 above 700 °C, and at the same time achieves in situ nitrogen doping. However, sometimes the g-C3N4 needs to be pre-synthesized and next flaked off, which in fact are troublesome procedures. (3) Although the KOH activation-based route can obtain ultrathin and large specific surface area graphene-like products, it needs to use the strongly corrosive KOH and the post-treatments of removing K compounds. (4) The distinct advantage of template-free method compared to the hard and soft template methods is simplifying the synthetic process without the tedious used-removed operations of 2D templates. However, the shortcoming lies in its weakness in precisely regulating the morphology and porosity of 2D products. Moreover, there exist many possibilities for the template-free strategies, and the advantages and disadvantages of each approach vary greatly. For instance, some biomass with original or predesigned layered structure, after assisting the freeze-drying technology, can transform into 2D products, but the thicknesses are as high as hundred nanometers or micrometer. After the direct carbonization of diverse leaves with obvious sheet structure, the products usually contain not only carbon nanosheets but also other bulky particles. Thus the additional treatments are required to separate high-quality nanosheets from the mixture. (5) In addition to biomass, biological molecules derived nanostructured materials have been a significant method to fabricate 2D materials due to the potential to precise control of the structure of matter in molecule level. Diverse nucleobases can lead to different supramolecular aggregation and functional nanostructure by pre-organization or self-assembly of small molecules guided by hydrogen bonding or π- π stacking interaction. Such hydrogen-bonding can be stable at relatively high temperature, which makes C–C or C–N polymerization happening in a 2D plane. In view of these, direct carbonization of nuclebases enables the formation of 2D carbon with highly sp2-conjugated and heteroatom doping feature. Based on above discussion, some perspectives suggest to be considered. One suggestion is further investigating the formation mechanism of biological molecules derived 2D carbons. By virtue of in-situ characterization methods, for instance, in-situ TEM can monitor real-time changes of the skeleton structure, conducive to recognizing the driving force behind the molecular assembly. Besides, theoretical calculations will be conducted to further confirm its authenticity or reveal other possibilities. These combined studies may contribute to more reasonable design of novel 2D carbon materials with desired microstructures. In view of the fact of more possibilities for the template-free strategies, there is still much room for further development and exploration. Thus another suggestion is continuing to develop more desirable methods to prepare high-quality 2D carbons, which aim to possess uniform morphology, ultrathin thickness, large lateral size, in-situ high-level heteroatom dopants and developed porous structure. The synthetic strategies should be more facile, efficient, controllable, flexible, low-cost, renewable and capable of large-scale production. Eng. 7 (2019) 11369-11376. Baobing Huang received her bachelor degree from Qingdao University of Science and Technology in June 2014, and received her Ph.D. from Fuzhou University in April 2020. During her Ph.D., she has been working on the synthesis of sustainable carbon materials in Prof. Zailai Xie's group. Her research interest now mainly focuses on the design and synthesis of 2D nanomaterials derived from biomolecules and their applications in energy-related fields. Yuchuan Liu received his bachelor degree from Guangxi University for Nationalities in 2015. He is currently a Ph.D. candidate in Prof. Zailai Xie’s group. His research focuses on the synthesis of metal-based carbon materials derived from biomass and their applications in electrocatalysis and energy storage. Prof. Zailai Xie received his bachelor degree at China University of Mining and Technology, Beijing in 2004. And later he received master degree at Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter (FJIRSM), Chinese Academic of Science in 2007. From 2007 to 2009, he was a research associate in the group of Prof. Xiao-Ying Huang at the FJIRSM. He completed his Ph.D. degree at the University of Potsdam and the Max Planck Institute of Colloids and Interfaces in Potsdam, Germany in 2012. He then joined the Department of Inorganic Chemistry as a post-doctoral worker, directed by Prof. Robert Schlögl at the Fritz Haber Institute of the Max Planck Society in Berlin. In 2014 he moved to the new Max Planck Institute for Chemical Energy Conversion in Mülheim a.d. Ruhr as a postdoc. Since 2015, he returned to College of Chemistry at Fuzhou University as a Distinguished Professor of “Minjiang Scholars” in Fujian Province, where he leads a research group on the sustainable carbon materials. His current research interests are green catalysis and energy materials. He is the author of over 80 articles and 2 book chapters. He also holds 4 patents.

coredata.dc:description: Two-dimensional (2D) carbon materials with ultrathin thickness, large lateral size, large surface area, accessible active sites and unique physical–chemical properties have been proven to be attractive electrode materials or catalysts for high-efficient energy storage and conversion materials. However, the conventional synthesis method for 2D carbon materials heavily depends on fossil-based feedstocks and goes through harsh conditions (e.g., chemical vapor deposition), which are unsustainable and costly. Besides, the top-down method needs to use massive strong acids/oxidants, which is environmentally-unfriendly. Therefore, it is necessary to commit to seek green, sustainable and cost-effective approach for the synthesis of 2D carbon materials. As of now, biomass or biological molecules as carbon-rich resources have been viewed as a promising candidate for the 2D carbon material preparation owing to its abundance, renewability, nontoxicity and low-cost. Especially for nucleobases, as an emerging molecule have been shown great advantages for the construction of 2D materials guided by its multiple hydrogen-bonding interaction. Recently, our group have proposed a rather innovative strategy to produce 2D carbon materials by carbonization of nucleobases which has relatively high electrode potentials. These nucleobases can form planar network structure through hydrogen bonding interaction. Such hydrogen-bonding can be stable at relatively high temperature, which confines C–C or C-N polymerization in a 2D plane. As a result, direct carbonization of nucleobases enables the formation of 2D carbon with highly sp2-conjugated and feature of heteroatom doping. This review systematically summarizes the recent development of the strategies to synthesize 2D sustainable carbon materials from biomass and biological molecules. The corresponding electrochemical applications such as lithium ion batteries, supercapacitors and fuel cell are selectively presented. At the end, the summary and future perspectives in this important field are provided to inspire further exploration.
